bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, August 14, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes his yellow fever project to Webster. He discusses his theory regarding the true location of Camp Lazear. Hench inquires if there is a map of the area from circa 1900, showing the relationship of this railroad track to the dimensions of Columbia Barracks.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, August 14, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Moran
August 14, 1940
Mr. Royal S. Webster
Chief Engineer
Havana Central Railroad
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Webster:
div1.p:
In April, I was in Havana doing some medical histor-
ical researches on the work of the U.S. Army Commission of 1900
(Dr. Walter Reed, chairman). They established an experimental
camp called “Camp Lazear” on the San Jose farm in Quemados.
Patients who developed experimental yellow fever there were
immediately brought to a tent hospital on the edge of Columbia
Barracks which was in 1900 on the approximate site of what is
now the Military City. In connection with my investigations, I
found that the Cuban government have, in my opinion, lost the true
site of Camp Lazear and marked the wrong site by a tree and memor-
ial sign about sixty-five feet beyond the far side of the railroad
track opposite the rear of the grounds of the Military City. I
will not bother you with the details of my investigation, but for
my purposes it is important to find out just when this railroad
track was laid down. One doctor thought it was in 1901. A Mr.
John J. Moran of Havana, one of those who took part in the investi-
gation, telephoned you and you told him that you thought it was
built between 1860 and 1865 and remained unchanged since then. I
am anxious to have your written statement to that effect as the
Cuban government has asked me to make a formal report to them.
Do you have any idea whether the Havana Railroad Co. has an old
map of that district in 1900, showing the relationship of this
railroad track to the 1900 dimensions of Camp Columbia or Columbia
Barracks? I am most anxious to find such a map. I appreciate
sincerely your great help in this matter.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
